deliberation: I checked the imperatives and the light imagery. Zion is addressed as a woman and told to act; this is personification. The 'light' and 'glory' are not literal illumination but metaphors for divine salvation and restored status.

instances.english_text: Arise, shine
vehicle: a woman getting up and shining/beam­ing
ground: capacity for deliberate action and display, transition from passivity to activity
agency and vitality
social-spiritual renewal
posture: encouraging summons to respond to salvation
instances.explanation: The city/people Zion is addressed with feminine singular verbs as if she were a woman who can rise and shine, personifying the community as a female figure.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּ֣י בָ֣א אוֹרֵ֑ךְ וּכְב֥וֹד יְהוָה֖ עָלַ֥יִךְ זָרָֽח
instances.english_text: for your light has dawned; the glory of the LORD has shone upon you
target: Zion’s restored condition and divine favor
ground: clarity, joy, hope, visibility, beginning of a new day
positive, transforming intervention
experience of salvation conceptualized as emerging into light
posture: assuring description of a divinely given change
instances.explanation: The coming of salvation and God’s favor is depicted as the arrival of light and the rising of God’s glory, using light as a metaphor for deliverance and honor.

deliberation: I examined whether the darkness and clouds are literal or symbolic. In context they depict a moral/spiritual condition over nations contrasted with divine light on Zion, forming one extended metaphor of darkness vs. light.

instances.hebrew_text: הַחֹ֙שֶׁךְ֙ יְכַסֶּה־אֶ֔רֶץ וַעֲרָפֶ֖ל לְאֻמִּ֑ים וְעָלַ֙יִךְ֙ יִזְרַ֣ח יְהוָ֔ה וּכְבוֹד֖וֹ עָלַ֥יִךְ יֵרָאֶֽה
instances.english_text: Darkness shall cover the earth, and thick clouds the peoples; but upon you the LORD will shine, and His Presence be seen over you.
target: the nations’ distress/ignorance vs. Zion’s salvation
vehicle: darkness and heavy cloud vs. shining light
contrasting states of obscurity and illumination
ground: darkness implies confusion, danger, alienation; light implies guidance, safety, favor
contrast between lostness and clarity
experience of God conceptualized as light overcoming darkness
posture: diagnostic and hopeful—judging the nations’ state yet promising Zion’s exaltation
instances.explanation: The verse uses the opposition of darkness and light to depict the moral-spiritual plight of the nations and the special revelatory presence of God upon Zion.

deliberation: I focused on "walking to your light" and "to the brightness of your rising." The nations are not literally guided by a physical lamp; Zion’s renewed glory is conceptualized as light to which they gravitate.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהָלְכ֥וּ גוֹיִ֖ם לְאוֹרֵ֑ךְ וּמְלָכִ֖ים לְנֹ֥גַהּ זַרְחֵֽךְ
instances.english_text: And nations shall walk by your light, kings by the brightness of your rising.
target: nations’ attraction to Zion’s God-given status and truth
vehicle: walking toward a source of light/brightness
ground: light guides and attracts; people move toward it for safety and clarity
Zion becomes a visible point of orientation
conversion and pilgrimage framed as movement toward light
posture: celebratory depiction of Zion’s future influence
instances.explanation: Zion’s restored, God-given glory is described as a light, and the nations’ turning toward her is pictured as walking toward that light.

deliberation: I considered whether commands to look are idiomatic and whether the family language is figurative. The main figurative element is Zion as a mother whose ‘sons’ and ‘daughters’ return, a metaphor of the city/community as a parent.

instances.hebrew_text: בָּנַ֙יִךְ֙ מֵרָח֣וֹק יָבֹ֔אוּ וּבְנוֹתַ֖יִךְ עַל־צַ֥ד תֵּאָמַֽנָה
instances.english_text: Your sons shall be brought from afar, your daughters like babes on shoulders.
target: the dispersed inhabitants of Zion returning
vehicle: children (sons and daughters) coming back to their mother and carried on the hip
ground: intimacy, belonging, care between mother and children
restored bonds and joyful reunion
city-people relationship conceptualized as motherhood
instances.explanation: Zion, a city/people, is spoken of as a mother whose children return and are carried, personifying the community and metaphorically casting its members as her sons and daughters.

deliberation: I noted internal emotional imagery and economic imagery. There is (1) Zion shining/glowing with joy; (2) the heart trembling and widening as an image of intense emotion; and (3) the ‘wealth of the sea’ representing transferred riches.

instances.english_text: As you behold, you will glow / be radiant
ground: radiance suggests joy, vitality, attractiveness
inward delight made visible
joy conceptualized as shining
instances.explanation: Zion is said to ‘glow’ or ‘shine’ when she sees the influx of her children and wealth, using brightness as a metaphor for exuberant joy.

instances.english_text: Your heart will throb and thrill / your heart will tremble and grow wide
vehicle: a heart that shakes and expands
organ with physical movement and change of size
ground: physical trembling and enlargement suggest intensity and openness
astonishment and joy described as bodily effects
emotion conceptualized as heart movement/expansion
instances.explanation: The community’s emotions are portrayed through the heart physically trembling and expanding, personifying the heart and metaphorically mapping inner experience to bodily change.

instances.english_text: For the wealth / abundance of the sea shall pass on to you
ground: the sea stands for maritime commerce and distant wealth carried over water
oceanic abundance evokes vast resources
economic gain conceptualized via seaborne plenty
instances.explanation: ‘The abundance of the sea’ uses the sea metonymically for the wealth moved by sea trade, signifying vast economic resources flowing to Zion.

deliberation: I evaluated whether the camels are literal caravans or figurative. The verse plausibly envisions real caravans, but the phrase ‘a multitude of camels shall cover you’ is hyperbolic imagery for overwhelming abundance.

instances.english_text: Dust clouds of camels shall cover you / A multitude of camels shall cover you
target: Zion’s experience of incoming tribute-bearing caravans
vehicle: being covered or blanketed by countless camels
ground: to ‘cover’ suggests being surrounded in great numbers
extreme abundance expressed by exaggeration
abundance conceptualized as a mass that covers the land
instances.explanation: The image of camels ‘covering’ Zion exaggerates the number of caravans to convey extraordinary abundance and honor.

deliberation: I looked for non-literal totals and cultic imagery. ‘All the flocks of Kedar’ is a sweeping total and likely hyperbolic, stressing comprehensive participation rather than an exact census.

instances.english_text: All the flocks of Kedar shall be assembled for you
target: resources and worship from nomadic peoples directed to Zion
vehicle: ‘all’ of Kedar’s flocks gathering to one place
ground: hyperbolic ‘all’ conveys fullness and magnitude, not a strict literal total
idea of complete participation
honor conceptualized as total tribute
instances.explanation: The phrase ‘all the flocks of Kedar’ overstates for effect, expressing that Kedar’s pastoral wealth in its entirety is devoted to Zion.

deliberation: I noted two explicit ‘like’ comparisons: people/ships arriving are compared to a cloud and to doves returning. These are classic similes, each a distinct image of mass, smooth movement, and homing.

instances.english_text: that float like a cloud
target: the approaching multitudes or ships coming to Zion
vehicle: a cloud drifting/flying across the sky
ground: light, gliding movement and large indistinct mass
visual impression of many together from a distance
numerous arrivals conceptualized as a single expansive cloud
instances.explanation: Those coming to Zion are compared to a cloud, highlighting their number and the smooth, lofty movement toward the city.

instances.english_text: and like doves to their cotes
target: the same incoming groups/ships heading to Zion
vehicle: doves hastening back to their windows/cotes
homing birds, swift and directed flight
ground: instinctive, eager return to a secure home
gentleness and peacefulness of doves
return to Zion conceptualized as homing behavior
posture: appreciative, awed stance at the sight of return
instances.explanation: The arrivals are likened to doves flying home to their cotes, emphasizing their eager, homeward movement and peaceful character.

deliberation: I examined the ‘islands’ and ‘name of the LORD’ language. The coastlands are treated as waiting, which presumes their inhabitants, and ‘name’ stands for reputation/honor. I grouped waiting with metonymy for the peoples, and treated ‘name’ as a separate metonymy.

instances.english_text: For the coastlands / islands await me
target: distant maritime peoples’ attitude toward YHWH
nations at the ends of the earth
ground: regions stand for their inhabitants (metonymy)
waiting expresses hopeful expectation
far-off nations conceptualized as remote shores longing for God
posture: depiction of reverent anticipation from afar
instances.explanation: The ‘islands’ represent the distant peoples who hope for God, and are personified as waiting, using place for inhabitants and attributing them an attitude of expectation.

instances.english_text: for the name of the LORD your God
ground: a ‘name’ stands for the person’s reputation and qualities
to act ‘for the name’ is to honor the person
divine character conceptualized via the notion of a name
instances.explanation: Here ‘the name of the LORD’ is a metonymy in which God’s name represents His honor, character, and fame among the nations.

deliberation: I considered whether the foreign rebuilding and royal service are literal. The clearest figurative element is God ‘striking’ Zion in anger and ‘having compassion’ in favor, where national calamity and restoration are cast as physical blows and renewed care.

instances.english_text: For in anger I struck you down, but in favor I take you back / had compassion on you
target: Zion’s experience of judgment and restoration
vehicle: striking someone and then showing compassion
ground: a blow represents punitive action; compassion represents renewed acceptance
historical hardships seen as God’s ‘blow’ and restoration as His mercy
divine governance conceptualized as bodily chastisement and care
posture: interpretive frame that recasts past suffering as discipline and present restoration as grace
instances.explanation: God’s judgment on Zion is metaphorically portrayed as striking her, and His restoration as having compassion, mapping historical events to bodily actions.

deliberation: I checked whether permanently open gates is literal or rhetorical. Gates that ‘never’ shut day or night form a hyperbolic and meristic picture of unbroken security and influx.

instances.english_text: Day and night they shall never be shut
target: Zion’s state of continuous safety and prosperity
vehicle: gates that are open all day and all night
unbroken temporal span (‘day and night’ = merism)
ground: in normal cities, gates close at night for security; never closing implies complete peace and unfailing access
‘day and night’ as merism signals totality of time
secure prosperity conceptualized as uninterrupted openness
posture: exaggerated promise of lasting peace and influx
instances.explanation: The claim that the gates will never be closed, ‘day and night’, is hyperbolic and uses a merism to present an idealized picture of total security and constant inflow.

deliberation: I looked for rhetorical overstatement or symbolic uses. The verse is a direct threat of destruction to non-serving nations; while severe, it reads as straightforward covenantal judgment without a distinct figurative image singled out.

I noted that ‘glory of Lebanon’ stands for its famous forests, and that ‘place of My feet’ is anthropomorphic temple language. These are two distinct expressions: a metonymy and a metaphor/anthropomorphism.

instances.hebrew_text: כְּב֤וֹד הַלְּבָנוֹן֙ אֵלַ֣יִךְ יָב֔וֹא בְּר֛וֹשׁ תִּדְהָ֥ר וּתְאַשּׁ֖וּר
instances.english_text: The majesty / glory of Lebanon shall come to you—cypress and pine and box
target: costly building materials for the sanctuary
Lebanon’s timber wealth applied to the temple
vehicle: ‘glory of Lebanon’ meaning its splendid trees
reputation and visible splendor of a region
geographic region and its natural assets
ground: Lebanon is famed for its trees; its ‘glory’ stands for those resources
a place’s glory is what makes it impressive
valued materials conceptualized via regional ‘glory’
posture: celebratory promise of foreign resources beautifying the sanctuary
instances.explanation: ‘Glory of Lebanon’ is a metonymy where Lebanon’s renown stands for its prized trees—cypress, pine, and boxwood—destined for Zion.

instances.hebrew_text: לְפָאֵר֙ מְק֣וֹם מִקְדָּשִׁ֔י וּמְק֥וֹם רַגְלַ֖י אֲכַבֵּֽד
instances.english_text: To adorn the site of My Sanctuary, to glorify the place where My feet rest
target: dwelling of God among His people
vehicle: a ‘place of My feet’ or footstool
resting-place for feet of a great king
ground: a monarch’s footstool is close to his person and reflects his honor
temple viewed as God’s earthly footstool, not literal feet
divine presence conceptualized via royal body-part imagery
posture: elevating the temple’s status by royal metaphor
instances.explanation: Calling the temple ‘the place of My feet’ metaphorically and anthropomorphically depicts it as God’s footstool, emphasizing His royal presence there.

deliberation: I weighed whether the bowing is literal court practice or stylized. The extreme posture ‘at the soles of your feet’ strongly heightens humiliation and reversal, and Zion as the ‘you’ remains a personified city.

instances.english_text: Prostrate at the soles of your feet shall be all those who reviled you
vehicle: extreme bodily abasement before a superior
ground: to be at someone’s feet signifies utter submission and humiliation
heightened by ‘soles of your feet’ as the lowest point
political subjugation conceptualized as physical prostration
posture: triumphant vindication of Zion over former oppressors
instances.explanation: Those who despised Zion are described as prostrating at the very soles of her feet, personifying Zion and using hyperbolic body-language to depict complete subjection.

deliberation: I considered the descriptors ‘forsaken’ and ‘hated.’ Applied to a city, this is personification; the move from abandonment to everlasting pride and joy is framed in relational-emotional terms.

instances.hebrew_text: תַּ֧חַת הֱיוֹתֵ֛ךְ עֲזוּבָ֥ה וּשְׂנוּאָ֖ה ... וְשַׂמְתִּיךְ֙ לִגְא֣וֹן עוֹלָ֔ם מְשׂ֖וֹשׂ דּ֥וֹר וָדֽוֹר
instances.english_text: Whereas you have been forsaken, rejected, with none passing through, I will make you a pride everlasting, a joy for age after age.
target: Zion’s status and reputation among peoples
collective experience of shame vs. honor
vehicle: a person forsaken and hated then made into everlasting pride and joy
ground: abandonment and hatred signify disgrace; being ‘pride’ and ‘joy’ signify honor and delight
city treated like a person with relational history
civic fortune conceptualized via personal rejection and glorification
posture: comforting reversal from shame to honor
instances.explanation: Zion, a city, is described as once ‘forsaken’ and ‘hated’ but made into everlasting pride and joy, personifying the city and using relational language hyperbolically (‘everlasting’, ‘generation to generation’).

deliberation: I focused on the nursing imagery. ‘You shall suck the milk of nations, suckle at royal breasts’ is not literal but an extended metaphor of Zion being nourished by the resources and favor of peoples and kings.

instances.hebrew_text: וְיָנַקְתְּ֙ חֲלֵ֣ב גּוֹיִ֔ם וְשֹׁ֥ד מְלָכִ֖ים תִּינָ֑קִי
instances.english_text: You shall suck the milk of the nations, suckle at royal breasts
target: Zion’s dependence on and enrichment by the nations
vehicle: a child nursing milk from a mother’s and royals’ breasts
ground: nursing connotes sustenance, dependence, and intimacy
nations and kings supply life-giving resources to Zion
international support conceptualized as maternal nourishment
posture: affectionate yet politically bold picture of dependence transformed into honor
instances.explanation: Zion is portrayed as an infant nursing from ‘the milk of the nations’ and ‘royal breasts,’ a vivid metaphor for being fed and supported by foreign peoples and their rulers.

deliberation: I distinguished between the metal-exchange promises and the closing clause. The clearest figure is ‘I will appoint Peace as your overseers and Righteousness as your taskmasters’—abstract qualities personified as officials.

instances.english_text: And I will appoint Well-being / Peace as your government, Prosperity / Righteousness as your officials
target: the nature of Zion’s future governance
vehicle: Peace and Righteousness as appointed overseers and taskmasters
ground: just officials should embody peace and righteousness; here those virtues themselves rule
government characterized entirely by shalom and tzedeq
good order conceptualized via personified virtues in office
posture: idealizing vision of ethically grounded governance
instances.explanation: Peace and Righteousness are personified as Zion’s leaders, expressing that her future administration will be wholly characterized by these virtues.

deliberation: I looked at the naming of walls and gates. The key figure is the renaming: ‘you shall call your walls Salvation and your gates Praise,’ which metaphorically attributes salvific and doxological character to the city’s defenses and entrances.

instances.english_text: And you shall name your walls ‘Salvation’ and your gates ‘Praise’
target: city’s physical structures as expressions of her condition
vehicle: abstract nouns used as proper names
ground: walls signify protection, hence tied to salvation; gates signify points of entry and public gathering, hence tied to praise
city’s structures embody her rescued and worshipful state
qualities conceptualized via personified, named architecture
posture: celebration of transformed identity and reputation
instances.explanation: By calling the walls ‘Salvation’ and the gates ‘Praise,’ the verse personifies and metaphorically loads the city’s structures with the realities of deliverance and worship.

deliberation: I analyzed whether the eclipse of sun/moon is literal cosmic change or metaphor. In poetic context, ‘the LORD shall be your everlasting light’ is a central metaphor: God’s presence replaces cosmic lights as the source of guidance and glory.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהָֽיָה־לָ֤ךְ יְהוָה֙ לְא֣וֹר עוֹלָ֔ם וֵאלֹהַ֖יִךְ לְתִפְאַרְתֵּֽךְ
instances.english_text: For the LORD shall be your light everlasting, and your God shall be your glory.
target: Zion’s unending experience of divine presence and honor
ultimate source of guidance and splendor
relationship between God and restored Zion
vehicle: everlasting light and glory replacing sun and moon
ground: light provides visibility, life, and joy; glory gives honor and beauty
God Himself supplies what sun and moon symbolize
divine presence conceptualized as unending daylight and splendor
posture: exalted, eschatological promise that transcends ordinary cosmology
instances.explanation: YHWH is described as ‘your everlasting light’ and ‘your glory,’ metaphorically casting His presence as a never-fading source of illumination and honor; the negation of sun/moon includes hyperbolic and meristic overtones.

deliberation: I saw continuation of the light motif: sun and moon no longer setting, and mourning ending, grounded in ‘the LORD shall be your everlasting light.’ This combines metaphor (prosperity as unsetting luminaries) with hyperbolic cosmic language.

instances.hebrew_text: לֹא־יָב֥וֹא עוֹד֙ שִׁמְשֵׁ֔ךְ וִירֵחֵ֖ךְ לֹ֣א יֵאָסֵ֑ף כִּ֣י יְהוָ֗ה יִֽהְיֶה־לָּךְ֙ לְא֣וֹר עוֹלָ֔ם
instances.english_text: Your sun shall set no more, your moon no more withdraw; for the LORD shall be a light to you forever
target: enduring blessedness and the cessation of grief in Zion
emotional and existential state of the community
vehicle: a sun that never sets and a moon that never wanes, constant light
ground: sunset and moon’s withdrawal mark endings and darkness; their ceasing symbolizes no more dark periods
perpetual light implies unbroken joy and security
eternal consolation conceptualized as a day without night
posture: triumphant, eschatological assurance that sorrow will never return
instances.explanation: The perpetual sun and moon, grounded in God as everlasting light, metaphorically depict an unending state of joy and security; the astronomy is hyperbolic to express permanent cessation of mourning.

deliberation: I noted two coordinated images: ‘the shoot/planting that I planted’ and ‘the work of My hands.’ Together they form one extended metaphor: the people are God’s cultivated planting and crafted handiwork.

instances.english_text: They are the shoot that I planted, My handiwork in which I glory.
vehicle: a plant/shoot that someone plants and a crafted work of the hands
ground: planting and crafting imply intentionality, care, and design
their righteousness and permanence reflect God’s work
people conceptualized as cultivated planting and crafted artwork
posture: affirmation of divine ownership and pride in His people
instances.explanation: The community is described both as ‘the shoot of My planting’ and ‘the work of My hands,’ a double metaphor presenting them as what God has carefully cultivated and crafted for His glory.

deliberation: I evaluated the numerical growth language. ‘The smallest shall become a thousand, the least a mighty nation’ is hyperbolic magnification, using family and nation categories to express dramatic expansion from insignificance to greatness.

instances.hebrew_text: הַקָּטֹן֙ יִהְיֶ֣ה לָאֶ֔לֶף וְהַצָּעִ֖יר לְג֣וֹי עָצ֑וּם
instances.english_text: The smallest shall become a clan; the least, a mighty nation.
vehicle: a tiny one turning into a ‘thousand’ / clan, a small one becoming a mighty nation
ground: from small to large signals extraordinary growth; numbers are inflated to stress magnitude
what is insignificant becomes prominent and powerful
divine blessing conceptualized as hyperbolic multiplication of size and status
posture: confident assertion of God’s ability to quickly elevate the lowly
instances.explanation: The transformation of ‘the smallest’ into a full clan and ‘the least’ into a mighty nation uses hyperbolic growth imagery to express radical expansion and elevation.
